claim: You can see the Statue of Freedom from the Statue of Liberty.

supporting.text: The Statue of Freedom is located atop the U.S. Capitol in Washington, D.C., while the Statue of Liberty is in New York Harbor, making them geographically too distant to be visible from one another.

attacks.text: The Statue of Freedom is located atop the U.S. Capitol in Washington, D.C., while the Statue of Liberty is in New York Harbor, making them geographically too distant to be visible from one another.
Under exceptional atmospheric conditions, such as a superior mirage, distant objects can sometimes become visible beyond the normal horizon.
The claim might be referring to a replica or miniature version of the Statue of Freedom located near the Statue of Liberty.
If interpreted metaphorically, 'seeing' could refer to understanding or appreciating the ideals represented by both statues, rather than literal visibility.

supporting.text: The curvature of the Earth prevents visibility between two points as far apart as New York City and Washington, D.C., even if no obstructions existed.

attacks.text: The curvature of the Earth prevents visibility between two points as far apart as New York City and Washington, D.C., even if no obstructions existed.

The Statue of Freedom is located in Washington, D.C., while the Statue of Liberty is in New York City, which are approximately 330 km apart. The curvature of the Earth would indeed obstruct direct line-of-sight visibility at this distance.
Atmospheric refraction can sometimes bend light over the horizon, making distant objects like lighthouses or mountains visible beyond the expected geometric horizon.
Atmospheric refraction effects are typically minor and unpredictable, and would not reliably make the Statue of Freedom visible from the Statue of Liberty under normal conditions.

supporting.text: No verified reports or photographs exist showing the Statue of Freedom visible from the Statue of Liberty, despite both being major tourist attractions.

attacks.text: No verified reports or photographs exist showing the Statue of Freedom visible from the Statue of Liberty, despite both being major tourist attractions.
The Statue of Freedom is located on top of the U.S. Capitol, which is approximately 225 miles away from the Statue of Liberty, making it impossible to see with the naked eye.
The curvature of the Earth would obstruct the view of the Statue of Freedom from the Statue of Liberty, even if they were closer together.
The Statue of Freedom is much smaller in size compared to the Statue of Liberty, further reducing the likelihood of visibility from such a distance.

supporting.text: The Statue of Freedom is a smaller structure (19.5 feet tall) compared to the Statue of Liberty (305 feet tall), making it impossible to see at such a great distance without magnification.

attacks.text: The Statue of Freedom is a smaller structure (19.5 feet tall) compared to the Statue of Liberty (305 feet tall), making it impossible to see at such a great distance without magnification.
The Statue of Freedom is located on top of the U.S. Capitol dome, which is approximately 288 feet tall, making it visible from the Statue of Liberty under clear conditions.
The distance between the Statue of Liberty and the U.S. Capitol is about 225 miles, far beyond the range of human vision even with elevation.
Atmospheric conditions, such as haze or pollution, would further reduce visibility over such a long distance.
